isis.stitle: TSI 03-12-10R - Belt Wear On International VT 365, T 444E, DT 466, and 530 Engines

subjectgroup.subject: Belt Wear On International VT 365, T 444E, DT 466, and 530 Engines

geninfo.para: International equipped vehicles that exhibit main drive belt wear on the front or rear edge of the fan belt may be experiencing alignment issues. Items to inspect are the alternator mounting, fan hub and automatic belt tensioner.

warning.para: To avoid property damage, personal injury or death, park the vehicle on a level surface, set the parking brake, chock the wheels and turn the engine off.

svcprocinfo.para: In general, placing a simple straight edge across the face of the alternator pulley can check belt alignment. Place the straight edge on the face of the alternator pulley and rotate it up to the fan hub pulley. The belt should maintain the same distance from the straight edge at the fan hub pulley as it is from the alternator pulley. The same procedure can be used to verify alignment to the tensioner, water pump pulley, and crankshaft pulley. Using this method will determine which pulley and/or drive system is out of alignment and needs adjustment using one of the following procedure(s).

step1.para: Remove the drive belt from the alternator pulley.
Loosen the top mounting bolt of the alternator.
Loosen the lower mounting bolt of the alternator. Make sure the bolt is loose enough that tapping the bushing rearward will provide clearance between the bushing and the mounting bracket.
Tighten and torque the top mounting bolt to 81-95 Nm (60-70 lbf-ft).
Tighten and torque the lower mounting bolt to 81-95 Nm (60-70 lbf-ft).
Install the fan belt. Make sure the belt is properly seated in the pulley grooves.

svcsubproc.title: Fan Hub (water pump mounted on V8s) with Viscous Fan Drive, Horton EC-450 Fan Drive, and BorgWarner Fan Drive (SFN 03-12 discusses Horton Drive Master mounting instructions)

step1.para: Remove the belt from the fan pulley.
Remove the four bolts holding the pulley to the fan hub, remove pulley.
Inspect the fan hub to make sure the bearings have not worked rearward toward the engine. If the bearing has moved, replace the hub and inspect the vehicle for an engine or driveline vibration.
If the fan hub does not need to be replaced, reassemble the hub and look for other component misalignment.

step2.para: Rust between the arm and the base
Rotation of the pulley and pivot of the tensioner arm must be free and smooth without any noise or roughness
Wear at the arm to base joint

step1.para: Replace tensioner if any of the above conditions are found.
